reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game combines elements of Crusader Kings, Risk, and Warcraft. At first I was leery about the warcraft aspects with the different races and heroes, since I play historical games with just people, but I might be warming up to it. I like the way the combat system works, it somewhat feels like a card game. Although, there should be a way to join your allies in battle. The de jure kingdoms, a Crusader Kings/Risk element, are fun. The campaign so far is great. The game feels like fast-paced game of Risk with added elements such as deciding whether to build up infrastructure or a bigger army. It's shaping out to be a great game.

Early Access Review

This game is a nice refreshing and easy to play RTS that doesn't take literal hours to get through a game. Mechanics are simple enough, yet not reductive in the way cross-platform strategy games can be. For those of you confused on why this is in the free to play section, while the full game costs 15.99, the email sent out to the mailing list reads as follows:

The Early Access build has a free demo section. You can grab an Early Access copy of the game from Steam RIGHT NOW and be playing for free within minutes (depending on your download speed). To get full access to the rest of the game

recommended: which will be $15.99 USD. This is a 25% discount from the full game price
hoursPlayed: which will be $19.99 USD on release."\n\nSo presumably

For those who complain that the game is advertised as NO free to play" while being in the "Free To Play" category: the game is actually try-and-buy (pay once and unlock everything)

Let's start from the beginning. I'm a working adult. I don't have much time to grind anymore (Work commitments, spouse, familystuff). I don't really play games on PC or consoles anymore because I can't afford the time and it's slightly sad to be on the PC for work all day, just to head on home and go on the PC to play games.

Anyways, I was one of the testers from the BETA period and back then, the game was DA BOMBZ (nobody says that anymore, do they?). It was the perfect TO-GO" game to come by in a loooong time

recommended: it sometimes doesn't help constipation when you're playing Multiplayer and pipped in the last TURN due to Victory Points). It also helped me get through some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ downtime during traffic rush hour. (Disclaimer: I do not advocate playing on ipad while driving

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This fills a nice little niche that not many games do.  Let's say you like strategy games, obviously, youre looking at this game right?  But maybe you don't have time to play Civ 5 or Endless Legend.  Or you don't want to make the time investment for those games right now.   What options do you have if you want to play a world conquering grand strategy game.  Not many.

In steps Legends of Callasia.  This game is akin to super Risk(the boardgame).  It's a dudes on a map game with some extra stuff thrown in to make more interesting.  That extra stuff includes heroes, you can't move armies around without them, ala Heroes of Might and Magic.  You also have cards that can boost your kingdom, think strategy cards, or can help in battle, think tactics cards.  These add enough flair to make it better than risk.  Throw in a bunch of different maps and multiplayer  and you've got a game you can get some mileage out of.

I did a quick video series shopwcasing the campaign, that you can check out if you want to see the game in action.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JOwS9qxK4jk

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSo, first of all, this seems like an incredibly fun game, I also really like that the race you're given to try is morally ambiguous. Seems like it has good mechanics, a fun singleplayer campaign, AND I actually saw another player online the other day! With all that said, I really found the F2P model to be underwhelming. Massive props to the devs for not using microtransactions, but it would be much better, in my opinion, to let the player try each faction. As it is, you get 2/8 of ONE faction to try. The other factions have 6 and 4 single player missions, but we don't even get a taste of them. My advice would be to either make one of each faction's missions free, or to write a separate tutorial" mission for each faction
date: which would be included in the free game. That way
recommended: I would be sure that I like more than 1/3 of the game before spending $16-22 for the full game. I don't think this would decrease the number of people buying the full game
hoursPlayed: as people would become even more intrigued by the new stories.\n\nIn conclusion
voteText: I absolutely loved the small bit of it that I was able to play
helpfulPercent: and I am considering buying the full version just based on that bit. However
votesHelpful: if I could even have a small taste of what the other factions were like
votesTotal: and they weren't a complete disaster
votesFunny: I would buy the full version of this game as fast as I physically could. Great game
column16: just wish the F2P model could be a bit better."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nLegend of Callasia is a game I am having trouble describing in words. you move your pieces on the board conquering territories and building fortifications on the way, while also fighting in card style battles during encounters. I guess the closest thing I own that is similar is the Total War Shogun 2 world map, where you move your hero and use unit cards. I dont know how much I recommend it yet as I have not played much, but I can say it seems really decent and worth the time to look. From what I can tell this free to play version acts as a sort of demo for the full game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is just a demo, there are only 2 playable maps which take around an hour to play, and one playable race. To unlock the other 15 maps and 2 other races you have to pay $16 USD.

The gameplay itself is ok, very simplified turn based strategy game with only minimal upgrades for provinces and towns, none for troops or heros. The AI is pretty weak, I could build an unbeatable army within 10 turns of each map, using only the starting territories, without being attacked.

This lack of depth combined with the very high price for content means I do not recommend this game. This is essentially a web based game dressed up on Steam with a massive hidden price tag. Stick to the actual free web based strategy games instead of this.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

Legends of Callasia is a game fused from 4X, card-battle, and Risk-type map domination genres.  Although I didn't play long, I played long enough to lose interest quickly, since the game's different systems left me wanting to play other similar, but better, games.  However, it is free so there is no reason not to try it for yourself.  Therefore, this review is pretty pointless, isn't it?

PROS
+ Lots of cards with varied powers spanning multiple factions
+ Ability to capture and improve land plots causes frequent strategic decisions
+ Heroes, units, and structures can be upgraded
+ Umm, FREE!

CONS
- Slow pace left me bored
- Not enough complexity left me wanting to play other similar games
- Many maps locked until previous levels completed (or behind paywall)
